body:
This switches from UTF8 to Unicode per #712 (and adds tests).

We're not totally sold on using Unicode over UTF8, as it means using output from `base64` on Linux will fail with `-EncodedCommand`. But not using Unicode means this feature does not work the same as on Windows.

As it stands, this PR resolves the code to act the same as PowerShell's [original behavior](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/hostifaces/PowerShellProcessInstance.cs#L98).

title: Fix xunit test fail in build

body:
According to @andschwa, xUnit packages do not allow us to set the default AssemblyLoadContext (see #850 ). So xUnit tests are running on core powershell without PS-ALC being its default ALC.

This basically means the xUnit tests are running in a different environment than the one we are going to present to users, and it could mean that the tests results are not accurately reflecting the truth.

This is a broader test infrastructure issue and we need to fix it.

title: Persistent History

body:
In order to start resolving #854 / #839 and enable a much easier packaging story for @raghushantha, we need to switch to the shared .NET framework.
- [x] Revert to RC2 bits
- [ ] Update documentation to refer to OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode#157 for debugging (Thanks @gregg-miskelly)
- [x] Depend on Microsoft.NETCore.App instead of NETStandard.Library
- [x] Remove superfluous package dependencies

Once this is done, the `powershell.deps.json` file will contain only the app's dependency closure (no FX assemblies). We could then:

> For each assembly enumerated, perform a Assembly.Load for it. Since the assembly would be listed in the TPAbinder, but not yet loaded, Assembly.Load will load it and return the reference that you can use. -- @gkhanna79

We would then not need to modify the type catalog.

/cc @daxian-dbw

title: Add New-PSOptions

body: **Do not merge, this is a bug repro** Per discussion with @daxian-dbw, `Assembly.Load` will fall back to the `ALC.Load` if it does not find the assembly. However, this highlights the problem with the PowerShell type analysis being coupled to assembly loading. Since `Assembly.Load` will successfully load the PowerShell assemblies (`System.Management.Automation` etc.) from the TPA (due to the publish layout of .NET CLI), PowerShell's custom `AssemblyLoadContext` is completely skipped, thus also leaving us without some PowerShell types, leading to very weird errors: ``` powershell ~/PowerShell |-/ & (Get-PSOutput) One or more errors occurred. (One or more errors occurred. (Value cannot be null. Parameter name: type)) (Value cannot be null. Parameter name: type) ~/PowerShell |-/ $Error[0] Unable to find type [System.Management.Automation.Language.Ast]. ``` @daxian-dbw and I are working to resolve this correctly and support each PowerShell deployment scenario in #839. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/854)

body: I forgot to revert this in #814, thanks @daxian-dbw for the pointer. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/853)

title: Enable xUnit tests on OS X

body: The latest xUnit packages fix the "could not resolve coreclr path" problem we were having. To resolve all dependencies, the cli-deps feed was replaced with the aspnet feeds. However, the latest xUnit packages do not allow us to set the default AssemblyLoadContext. So we have to allow PowerShell to continue with a test harness's ALC. We do not (yet) support running the tests on OS X, so we pretend they pass for now. This resolves #806. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/850)

title: Enable OS X tests on Travis

body:
While setting up the OS X build, I encountered a funny issue. Running `ulimit -n 4096` inside PowerShell had no effect, so I had to run it before launching the PowerShell process. Now, `ulimit` is both a Bash built-in and a native command on OS X. My guess is that, when running from PowerShell, it was launched as a child process (of course) and so the system call to `setrlimit` only affected the launched child process, not PowerShell itself.

I think the appropriate fix would be to add a built-in `ulimit` function to PowerShell that called `setrlimit` in-proc, thus modifying the current process's open file descriptor limit.

This is a total edge case that we should take care of at some point, but I don't think it's super high priority.

When running PowerShell Core on Nano, the `Clear-Host` command fails due to an unsupported `System.Console.SetBufferContents` call.

I think the fix would be to modify the function to just call `cls.exe` directly, and catch any errors around `System.Console`.

The [current implementation](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/76ad94d8a760cd3f865e2dcb151287ce33e0cd5d/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/InitialSessionState.cs#L4725) clears the host manually with calls to `$RawUI.SetBufferContents`.

body:
## Move to GitHub

This issue tracks problems we faced, when we tried to move development.
It's divide into buckets.
#### Source parity

There are two parts: we cannot build some code as-is (i.e. we need `#if !CORECLR` guards), we don't build some things yet (completely or replaced with stubs)
- [x] #760  Replace Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.Native by the real package on Full CLR build
- [x] ~~#745 Use C# bindings in EventLog code~~ (out of scope)
- [x] ~~#726 Replace FlashExtract sources by Nuget packages~~ (out of scope)
- [x] #683 FullCLR version should build x64 powershell.exe
- [x] ~~#670 Add controlpanelitemcommand.cs to Full CLR build~~ (out of scope)
- [x] ~~Submit `#if !CORECLR` guards and `<windows.h>` (from powershell.exe) to our current branch in source depot~~
- [ ] We don't build all existing in the product artifacts. #1031
#### Process problems
- [x] ResGen is missing from `dotnet cli` (we workaround it with `Start-ResGen` + submodule, but it complicates the process). 
- [x] It's pretty hard to maintain two long-living branches at the current state of the repo: massive re-namings need to be carry-around as cherry-picks. It would be viable, when structure would settle better.
#### Regressions in the GitHub binaries
- [ ] #543 BVT/DRT Regressions
- [x] #547 New-Object -Com doesn't work for custom Com objects
- [ ] BVT/DRT run for binaries from the proposed branch [`server2016-old`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/tree/server2016-old) is not clean.
- [x] We use artificially crafted NuGet packages as dependencies from local [`nuget-feed`](https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-windows-build/tree/master/nuget-feed). It allows us to build binaries, but they are failed to load from GAC in runtime.
title: Parity with windows dev workflow (aka move to github)

body: When an assembly that exists outside of the trusted platform assembly list but in the GAC on Windows was loaded, the use of `Assembly.Load` before the `LoadFromAssemblyPath` caused a recursive loop to occur. By attempting to load from the file path first, we avoid this loop. However, loading TPA assemblies by their path throws an exception, so now we catch this particular exception and attempt the load through `Assembly.Load`. @daxian-dbw, I really don't like this solution, as it relies on catching the exception from the failed load-by-path. However, we do need to support the .NET CLI scenario with the PowerShell assemblies exist in the TPA. To do this properly I think means breaking the coupling of the type analysis and assembly loading, so that we can analyze SMA etc. for their cmdlets, without having to re-load them. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/powershell/powershell/814)
title: Fix stack overflow exception when loading assemblies

From: Wim Coekaerts:

... the binary and libraries and a bunch of ps1xml files are all in /usr/local/share/powershell. Would it make sense to separate them out in bin/  lib/ etc/ ?   In fact, even though for ‘3rd party’ it’s typically a good idea to have things in /usr/local or so… at least in the old days, there’s also possibly /usr/ (like anything native) or /opt/Microsoft/ or so. This can be religious some times with some folks but I think a bit of a split of bin/lib would be good either way – location-wise  usr/local/ is not bad but I am not sure if that’s typical any more.
